I discussed it with Tyler some months ago, and he actually told me 
the sam=
e, that he evolved it to oscillate its legs first. 
I took a different path=
 - I rewarded cyclic activity in the hips and 
knees as well as distance tr=
avelled. Besides, I used FS-NEAT and only 
4 outputs for the legs. Very sim=
ple. :)
With this approach, NEAT was able to find NNs that have just about =
5-
6 connections, oscillating the 4 outputs and moving the legs. It was 
wa=
lking (running forward in fact) and I was very very happy :) 
My problems s=
tarted when I added the head, the arms and the feet. 
From 4 outputs they b=
ecame 15. This enlarged the search space a lot, 
and the FS-NEAT approach u=
sually connected.. like your left feet 
connected to your neck and I want y=
ou to walk - it doesn't work :) 
Using a fully connected CTRNN is like a fi=
xed-genome evolution so I 
dropped that as well. 
I decided to use HyperNEA=
T and give it a substrate that is close to 
the human's actual geometry in =
space. Left is left, right is right, 
up and down... 
The inputs are locate=
d in the center and are a 3D vector, 
representing the head's current veloc=
ity. It's like the.. organ found 
in the middle ear (can't recall how to ex=
press that in english :)) 
The hidden neurons are organised in a circle aro=
und these inputs. 
The outputs have green color and: the topmost is the nec=
k's joint 
desired angle. The arms are located below it in the left and rig=
ht 
sides of the substrate. Each arm has 3 outputs. The legs are 
organised=
 in a similar manner, and each leg has 4 outputs. 

Peter

--- In neat@yaho=
ogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Peter,
> 
> I beli=
eve the challenge in this domain is indeed the fitness 
function 
> as oppo=
sed to the learning method.  The problem is that it is very 
> difficult to=
 describe exactly what should be rewarded early on.  
> Rewarding # of step=
s tends to encourage a single flailing step yet 
> misses better oscillator=
y behavior.  Even if an individual does 
learn 
> a leg-based oscillation, =
it will likely fall and therefore never be 
> noticed.
> 
> When Tyler Stre=
eter was working on this problem in his Verve 
project 
> (http://www.vrac.=
iastate.edu/~streeter/verve/gallery.html), which 
> used NEAT with leaky-in=
tegrator neurons, I discussed this problem 
> with him often.  I believe he=
 ended up finding a clever way to 
reward 
> oscillatory behavior.  That is=
 the most important thing, since it's 
> really the key to walking: it's ne=
cessary for the circuit to 
produce 
> an oscillating pattern.  I may be re=
membering wrong, but I think he 
> may have started getting it to work by h=
anging the biped from an 
> invisible "string" from the ceiling, so that it=
 could not fall, and 
> simply training it to oscillate its legs.  Have you=
 tried 
discussing 
> it with Tyler?
> 
> By the way, can you please remind=
 me what the inputs and outputs 
are 
> on your substrate?
> 
> ken
> 
> --=

1.0; ?

es

can't

cyclic

same

ctually the 
same

ng. A way to

s for the model..

way =

the

verage_Head_Height with Total_Distance_Travelled in the fitness

on.

ic
